results.content:
Ive only gotten about half way through, but so far he basically reads all the bootstrap documentation out to you but doesn't explain a damn thing about how any of it actually works.

4-5 hours of just having the documentation read out to you makes for an EXTREMELY painful and monotonous, un-immersive learning experience.

It would be much better to have a practical "endgoal project" to make in EACH section, reviewing what we learn in that section as well as having some precursors as to what we'll be learning next, instead of leaving them all to the end, no matter how simple they may be.

This would allow for people on a tight schedule to skim through, check up on the end project of each section to see if they understand everything they need to know, and if they find theres something they don't understand they can go back and watch that one video. 

This would lead to a much smoother learning experience and would allow for people to learn at their own pace instead of sitting through repetitive shit in case they miss something important.

The templates you receive are pretty cool, but feel excessively repetitive in parts (particularly the colors. do we really need to do every single variation of everything)
results.content_html:

results.content:
Excuse me for my english, but i try to do my best : i am on the mizuxe project and i'am surprised by your practices in SCSS. When you have a grid whith default variables, you don't have to change the native scss. You must declare the new value of your variable in your style.Scss (or custom, etc..). It will change the value and you don't have to change bootstrap natives files. Another thing is that you use position absolute when you don't have too....​  And you indicate a font in REM but you dont say if we have to calculate the ratio px/REM or not. So this is intersting to see, but in a professionnal environment, with a reel design made by a graphist, you have to make a good conversion.
I think that it's better to show best practices and to take 2/3 minutes to explain SASS width bootstrap. Like what's the font-size ? what are the default value ? how can you use include and mixins and understand the mixins/includes existing in bootstrap ?
The sandbox is a good idea, the exercices too. It's a good course but i think you have to explain more best scss practices. :)
results.content_html:

results.content:
Brad seems very knowledgeable about Bootstrap and it's awesome that he re-did his videos to reflect the latest version as their were some syntax changes between the Alpha and Beta versions of 4.0.

On the downside, he basically presented the Bootstrap documentation which, while needed to see all the different classes, it just went on and on and on. Personally I would like to see him mix it up a bit; show the classes and then jump to a web page and show a couple in context to something you might have to do in the real world.  I just didn't get a sense of connection between the material presented and how they work on a given page.

While he did present example projects at the end, they were very basic. I would have liked to see him roll up his sleeves and show how you can customize a website by overwriting Bootstrap rules to make a website that doesn't necessarily have the Bootstrap "look". Also examples of more types of pages would have been valuable as well.

results.content:
Course was well thought out and comprehensive. All aspects of bootstrap 4 beta (the newest version) are covered through both in-depth explanations and great course projects. My favorite was the Glozzom Theme, although Portfoligrid was a close second! 

Project-based learning is more hands-on and fun for me, so if that is your learning style you will really enjoy this course! 

Even if this course just came with the Bootstrap 4 Starter Pack it would've been well worth the money. I've been able to use it in other personal projects to build sites faster using Bootstrap.

Great work, Brad!

results.content:
Brad went through the course in a reasonable manner. The course is constructed in a very organized way, that makes sense and allows the learner to get engaged. There were a handful of helpful explanations that allowed me to grasp the concepts better. 

The only thing I would advice is to be careful with the last two projects, and I would recommend to do them slowly (and avoid rushing). While Brad does his best to explain everything on the videos, there were many mistakes here and there in them. I had to spend hours debugging one of the projects for mistake that he had made on the original video. Nonetheless, it was still good learning experience (although frustrating for a bit because the code was almost identical to the one on the final project). 

Otherwise, this is probably an underrated course that deserves more attention. I have seen his videos on YouTube, and I have learned a lot. He is a natural teacher. Keep it up!

results.content: This is the second Bootstrap 4 course that I have taken on Udemy and the first of Brad Traversy's courses and I thoroughly enjoyed the class. Brad's course is the better of the two Bootstrap 4 courses that I have taken and a big reason for that is that this course takes you through five full length projects, including  two large, multi-page projects. As a self-taught web developer, getting to add the five projects that Brad walks you through is very valuable. I now have five new projects in my portfolio, some of which are complex, that I can point to and say, yes I do have a measure of understanding of what it takes to put together a large, complex web page.

results.content:
I liked the sandbox and the effort Brad put into designing that playground where we explored the pieces/functionalities of Bootstrap 4. That serves as a good reference.
The projects were also very informative and helped me see the way Brad goes about creating the different parts that make up a web page/project in general and with Bootstrap.
I recommend this course to anyone looking for a way to quickly style their web pages, make them responsive without having to spend a lot of time writing CSS.
Thanks a lot for the course, Brad!

results.content:
Was a big fan of the MERN: Front to Back course so I came here to get better at building interfaces. The sandbox stuff isn't all too useful, it's a video version of the Bootstrap documentation which is already good enough, and definitely not worth money. Though the projects are a great way to consolidate knowledge and pickup some intuition on how to use Bootstrap components, widgets, flexbox, and grid properly in a real development setting which makes the course still very useful. I personally think the course should be reduced to just the projects cause it would be a significant time-saver and probably more effective to simply just skim the documentation for an introduction of Bootstrap. Very high quality and clear course though; the great quality you get from Brad.

For those taking the course, I recommend reading the bootstrap documentation, and if that isn't adequate for you to start building some interfaces, then pick up this course and skip right to the projects to see how Brad utilizes Bootstrap to build real interfaces.

results.content: Overall I accomplished the goal of learning the ins and outs of bootstrap, but it's not my first choice of learning style. Half the class is going through a ton of classes one by one. It's basically a video version of the Bootstrap documentation. The second half was better because you learn how to actually learn to utilize all the classes we flew through in the first half. Although, it was mostly just me trying to catch up to what he was typing. I think this course would benefit from some "assignments", where we actually have to build it ourselves instead of copying the instructors code word for word.

results.content:
Excellent overview of Bootstrap as a framework and also of the changes introduced in version 4.

I gave 4 stars because occasionally the author should give more background information about the native CSS properties that are used under the hood by Bootstrap.  It doesn't have to be in-depth, but for example, it could have helped complete beginners to give a bit of a primer on the native Flexbox properties before using the Bootstrap 4 Flexbox-powered classes.  I am familiar with native Flexbox and while I was watching some lessons I thought that some concepts should have been presented with more context in comparison to the native Flexbox properties in order for beginners to understand which native Flexbox properties the actual Bootstrap classes come from.  Maybe just a Flexbox primer video before introducing the Bootstrap Flexbox-powered classes would help complete beginners and Flexbox newbies.

The other small detail I would mention is that there are a couple of places in the videos where the author uses un-elegant hacky solutions to quickly solve a problem and go on with the example project.  This is ok for more experienced viewers because they will understand that these are quick fixes because the focus of the course is not to learn JavaScript or CSS in-depth but for newbies I found that it's always better to use elegant and more production-ready solutions, even if they are not the focus of the course.  This allows students to pickup more tips and tricks that are elegant and also it shows that great development should have rigor and hacky solutions will usually come back to haunt you later on in realworld projects.

These are just suggestions to improve the course even more since it's already a great course and I definitely recommend it.  Brad is a great teacher and his courses are engaging to watch and he codes along with you at a good pace.

results.content:
I enjoyed the thorough introduction to Bootstrap and appreciated that the course requires no prior knowledge of Bootstrap 3. However I felt that the course did not go in-depth enough. It was more of an overview of all the features, components, layout, and such. A lot of the lecture time was spent typing out the example code which I fast-forwarded often since it could be a bit slow and repetitive. The purpose of buying this course was to benefit from sample code and projects; therefore it was helpful to use his downloaded code to jump-start my projects and visualize the results. 

Overall I feel that this course doesn't teach far enough beyond the Bootstrap website tutorials, though I do believe that watching videos is better than reading text. After going through the sections I still had loads of questions such as how to do more complex responsive layouts by combining many of the grid and sizing and component classes. I wish the instructor offered more real-world advice and recommendations and web-design guidance beyond knowledge.

I'm total novice with bootstrap but have some code experience from uni where I did computer networking so this wasn't too difficult. I imagine for someone completely new to this it would be fine, but when it gets to the font awesome some people might not know they can just grab the one from the boiler provided. It could do with a tiny update just to help people out with that. I think font awesome uses a script now. I have no idea how it works. Overall. I'm a happy customer thus far and I've had fun learning this. The tutor here explains everything with clarity and although you may need to pause a bit with time everything makes more sense. 

Great course. Highly recommend.

results.content: Really enjoyable course. I've done a couple of full stack courses in the past which can often glide over the the more in depth front end stuff and had left me scratching my head when I see something on the front end that looks amazing... but I'm left with no clue how to do it. This course very much filled in those gaps. Even the general setup of VS Code with Emmet and the various plugins have made my web dev life much easier! If you love the look of the Bootstrap style and want to expand your knowledge on it... this is definitely the course for you. Cheers!

A good, clear course on Bootstrap 4.

There is a certain amount of repetition in the course, which may be useful if you are very new to CSS/Bootstrap but it didn't have that much added value to me.
And what I found weird, is to see that parts of the projects are styled using CSS with custom classes, where SCSS variables and/or default Bootstrap 4 options could just as well be used. I mean: why do styling yourself, when you could be using Bootstrap?

results.content:
I recently took a beginner's guide to web development that lightly touched on bootstrap. I was really intrigued by it but unfortunately it was for a previously outdated version of bootstrap. Brad's course has been amazing in helping me get up to date with the latest version of bootstrap (bootstrap 4). 

Brad quickly goes over the fundamentals of bootstrap very quickly and in great depth in the first part of his course. This "Sandbox" as he calls it seems to be a great reference for both those who are new to bootstrap or those seasoned veterans looking for a quick refresher. 

The remaining parts of this course focus on making projects with bootstrap. These projects are well constructed and could serve as the examples of work for a portfolio, if you're looking to get into a front-end development job. 

I cannot stress how much I enjoyed this course! The pace was swift and amazing. Although it was a lot to take in, the course remained engaging and I did not find myself becoming tired or distracted at all. 

I've actually loved this course and have been blown away by Brad's teaching style that I've purchased a few more of his courses with the hopes that I can learn something new in as pleasurable of a course as this one.

results.content:
Before starting any lecture, I would like to see how the section looks like. Nesting a div in another div without an idea of what I'm coding, is difficult to understand and imagine for a visual person, which most front-end developers are. I struggled a lot throughout the entire course and I'm happy that is finished. For me, it was "look how I code, and follow what I do". Don't get me wrong, the projects are really great and modern looking, but the way of teaching is bad. 

It would be 5 stars, if at the beginning of the lecture, was explained how to achieve a certain part of the page, and would be left a room for self-coding while a video is paused. Once it's done, unpause it and see how the teacher's completed it. But without seeing what I'm actually coding, it is not possible.

results.content:
I finished this course and I think it was pretty good! The instructor provided tons of useful information and the course content was actually fun to do! 

The sandbox project helps a lot to get the hang of Bootstrap, and have a project that you can go back anytime you need reference. The other projects also teach a good load of useful ways to do what is needed while making a responsive site. 

I enjoyed how the course included 3rd party libs that are really useful (like a WYSIWYG editor or Lightboxes). 

The only few bad things I found is that the instructor seems to no longer respond to questions and the students need to depend on each other, which can be unlucky if you stuck at somewhere and there are no other students doing the course at the same time to help you. (Well, you can still turn to previous Questions, Google and Stackoverflow). Also there are a couple of mistakes the instructor makes during the course (especially at accordion menus) but most of the time, students pointed this out.

Overall, I really suggest this course. Worth the time and the money.

Thank you, Brad! :)

Brilliant course. I started learning front-end development from scratch last year and have been working through a couple of instructors on Udemy. Brad is really clear in his explanations and demonstrations. 

What was particularly good was that the projects are slightly different (i.e not just creating 5 websites with different colours) there is also some brief explanations and use of jQuery which I think would be a great course for Brad to build. I would certainly sign up. 

Thanks again Brad, really took my bootstrap skills to a new level.

The only reason I knocked off half a star is because some of the videos were blurry during the sandbox section. But despite that I was able to keep rolling through because Brad thoroughly explains each step. There were parts where I just listened and typed. Hopefully this problem can be remedied. Nevertheless, that wouldn't have worked with a lesser instructor. The video cleared back up by the time the projects rolled around and this course gave me my money's worth. Brad is the best instructor I have found.

results.content:
I have to say that I did thoroughly enjoy this course and I feel like Brad has a very good way of explaining what he is doing and I can honestly say I have learned quite a bit from this course and realized a lot things aren't as hard as they appear.

However a few minor issues with the course with the main one being the fact there really isn't any support if you get stuck and you better hope whatever is wrong has already been solved by another user and posted in the question section because if you ask a question you most likely wont get a response. The other minor issue would be outdated random splash photo in I believe the first website you make but I can't blame this on Brad because everything is constantly changing which is what brings me back to the no support option. Luckily another user had the same issue as me and I was able to progress.

The other issue is with Koala with the Sass website and the fact I spent three days trying first to use Koala with no success and even tried implenting Sass with my command line with no luck and ended up having to skip that website section entirely. 

Even with the issues I faced I feel this course was well worth the money and time invested and I will continue watching Brad's courses and hope he makes more of them because he is a great teacher.

The other issue is with Koala with the Sass website and the fact I spent three days trying first to use Koala with no success and even tried implenting Sass with my command line with no luck and ended up having to skip that website section entirely.

Even with the issues I faced I feel this course was well worth the money and time invested and I will continue watching Brad's courses and hope he makes more of them because he is a great teacher.

results.content: This class was great! I had a little experience with Bootstrap 3, and this was the only in-depth class I could find on the most current version. The instructor was awesome! He set the class up where you begin in the "sandbox", learning what all you can do with Bootstrap, and essentially working your way through the documentation in real life. He then followed the up with five excellent real-world projects to show you how it all comes together. Don't hesitate to buy this course!

results.content:
The instructor is excellent, the reason I took 1/2 star off is because of the use of "npm" and "gulp" which he has taken off for the new version and which I will take again when its out.
I would like more comments on the code because it is a fast paced course. Bootstrap 4 is like 2nd nature to him, he is very knowledgeable about the subject so he is practically running through the videos. I am sure the 2nd time I do the class, when he updates it without "npm" and "gulp" that I will be more familiar with everything and, hopefully, it will seem as a slower pace than this first time around.
I am very pleased with the class and I am looking forward to go through the updated version.
By the way, my comment  "seems to be running through the videos" is not meant to be negative, he explains in detail as he is going though the code, it looks to me that way because I did not know Bootstrap, first time looking at it, and I have not done a lot of web page development either, I am a 'back-end' PHP, and java developer.
I strongly recommend the instructor and the course.

results.content: This is a very good course, well worth the time and it goes into pretty much every feature of Bootstrap. The 'sandbox' section is quite repetitive, but as Brad mentions a few times, this is to cement your knowledge of all of the features. The projects are good to work through and the finished pages can serve as templates for your own future designs for those quick-turnaround & low-budget type projects.

results.content:
I sincerely liked the course:-) I do not have any background in Bootstrap and yet I could follow along quite easily. I could see the power of CSS and Bootstrap and how it could enhance the look and feel of web UI.

Hopefully, I would like to apply some of the things that I learned here and create a site of my own! At a minimum, I am sure, I would be able to understand what my team writes ( I am a project manager) and the code that is generated when developing ASP .NET web applications - I am also a Microsoft ASP .NET developer.

I would certainly recommend for those not possessing this UI skill which has eluded me for long.

results.content: This course was exactly what I needed. It has five projects that provide step-by-step practice to feel more comfortable with Bootstrap. The videos are a fantastic resource. The instructor uses an extension to reduce typing time. If you're totally new to Bootstrap, that might be more challenging, but it was a good way to test what I knew and that extension will be helpful when I'm more comfortable with Bootstrap. Great course overall. The instructor is easy to understand and explained the subject well.

results.content:
OVERALL: I love Brad's courses. I followed him over here from Safari/Eduonix. His courses are very good and I have purchase several. Brad does move a bit too fast though. I know he's trying to get through the material expeditiously, but he sometimes makes mistakes and has to go back and fix them. If he slowed down a tad, that could actually *save* time not having to retrace his steps. 

AREAS OF IMPROVEMENT: I also wish Brad would explain **WHY** he is making the decisions he makes in the code. The preliminary videos were a good primer, but I took this course over an entire month and didn't remember some of the things he discussed in earlier lessons. It would have been nice to get more detail and theory behind what he was doing so that I could not only *learn HOW*, but *understand WHY*. For example, it would be nice for him to give a brief overview of the BS4 components used in each project. He could show the final version of the project and mention the classes he'll be using, etc. He does this sometimes, but not consistently.

BENEFIT: Overall, Brad gives me the PRACTICE I need to actually apply the skills I'm learning. More theory would be helpful, however.

NOTE: Although the course wasn't recorded long ago, Bootstrap 4 was updated yet again and Font Awesome version 4 is now deprecated, so things in the first project (and likely subsequent projects don't work as they did when this was recorded. I was able to shim Font Awesome to continue using it anyway, but version 5 made several changes and the course needs to be updated to reflect that.

results.content: If you know Brad, you know that the quality will be there. This course is a fantastic way to get to know Bootstrap in depth. Brad goes over the basics in the first half of the course, which is essential and other courses lack. Then, the projects section is amazing with beautiful UI designs with his style. Bootstrap is at the lower spectrum of the web dev learning curve, so no back-end projects are included. He also touches on Sass (with a whole project) and how to integrate Sass to Bootstrap projects, using Koala. I can't recommend highly enough! Thank you, Brad for taking the time and Udemy for making it available at discounted prices. You have no idea how many lives you are changing.

results.content:
The intro information provides me with an adequate preview of what to expect. Thanks.

[At the halfway point] 
(I like that Udemy prompts for a review update mid-way through the course. Guessing not a large percentage of folk get here. Glad I'm pushing through!)

I really enjoyed learning the basics of Bootstrap 4. I was able to make a nice workflow, following Brad (the instructor) as he would lecture on the core elements of BS. After each logical section, I'd pause the video and replicate the code he had just shown. At the end of a lecture, going back through the code and really working to understand what just happened greatly helps me to lock in the knowledge.

Now that I'm into the first "project" (LoopLAB), I find the "learning" a bit different, and not quite as complete.

While still attempting to follow along with Brad's lectures, pausing, replicating the code (vs. simply watching the videos and/or using the final code), I feel I'm getting less knowledge.

Brad simply tells you what he's coding for next. And that's fine, however, it doesn't really address (for me, at least) the theory of how to extrapolate the code required to make the design happen. I would desire to hear more about how to break down the design and then how to make code which will render to the working web page.

But not going to change my 4.5 star rating at this point. Still feels like a valuable course and expenditure of learning time.
results.content_html:
The intro information provides me with an adequate preview of what to expect. Thanks.

[At the halfway point]
(I like that Udemy prompts for a review update mid-way through the course. Guessing not a large percentage of folk get here. Glad I'm pushing through!)

I really enjoyed learning the basics of Bootstrap 4. I was able to make a nice workflow, following Brad (the instructor) as he would lecture on the core elements of BS. After each logical section, I'd pause the video and replicate the code he had just shown. At the end of a lecture, going back through the code and really working to understand what just happened greatly helps me to lock in the knowledge.

Now that I'm into the first "project" (LoopLAB), I find the "learning" a bit different, and not quite as complete.

While still attempting to follow along with Brad's lectures, pausing, replicating the code (vs. simply watching the videos and/or using the final code), I feel I'm getting less knowledge.

Brad simply tells you what he's coding for next. And that's fine, however, it doesn't really address (for me, at least) the theory of how to extrapolate the code required to make the design happen. I would desire to hear more about how to break down the design and then how to make code which will render to the working web page.

But not going to change my 4.5 star rating at this point. Still feels like a valuable course and expenditure of learning time.

results.content: As I can judge, Brad is a really experienced Full Stack Developer with really good experience. For such a topic, the course has a optimal length and the pace chosen is also quite good. The projects he presents are a good reference and starting point for own projects. Compared to other courses, that I attended, I missed a lot of deeper explanations of how the different parts of Bootstrap are composed and work together. For more technical students there should be diagrams and cheatsheet to explain the big picture and the construction. However, the course shows a lot of components in real-world projects - a further self-study of the corresponding Bootstrap documentation is very helpful too.

results.content: I think that the course, so far, has done a good job of showing the capabilities of Bootstrap and how to utilize them. The sandbox is a great idea, and I love knowing I will have a useful resource when the course is over. I do find that there is a lack of detail on how some of these things work though. Making an element stick to the top for instance - it would be nice if the video explained how if two elements that have the sticky-top class are in the same container (live a div), then the second will overlap the first, but if they are in separate divs, the second will push the first up. And with drop down menus, how are the items in a menu being associated with a certain button? Is there something in the CSS of Javascript that binds a div with the class "dropdown-menu" to the preceding button with the class "dropdown-toggle", and does the div need to go right after the button?

results.content: Before I found this course, I was taking an outdated Bootstrap to Wordpress course using the old Bootstrap 3. The instructor didn't provide much outside of a code along, so I didn't really understand what I was doing. You will have no such problem with  this instructor. Brad Traversy builds his courses to be modular. You'll be able to go in-depth on every bit of Bootstrap 4. Aside from the card-decks and card-groups (which he touches on in the last project, this course covered every single aspect of bootstrap.  He then shifts the gears of the course. You'll go from learning the language to applying the language, and it's phenomenal. You'll learn to apply Bootstrap, you'll learn other industry tools, and you'll build amazing websites. Moreover, at this point in the course there's a Q&A where most students have already gone through the hurdles, so you're almost guaranteed to find a solution to whatever problem you run into whilst coding. I don't just recommend this course. I recommend this instructor.

results.content:
I  used Bootstrap 3 extensively and needed to quickly ramp up on Bootstrap 4 in order to start integrating it into work projects and to create a Bootstrap 4 Theme for my employer.

Overall, I enjoyed this course but must admit it was difficult to complete. After completing the third project, the projects started to feel like overkill, but I'm glad I completed them because they are all a bit unique and I can see ways to repurpose them for other learning activities. It felt a lot like practice drills on the piano (e.g. playing scales over and over again). It gets boring, but you develop the necessary muscle memory to use the framework effortlessly. If you are just getting started with the course, keep this in mind and do try to finish all of the projects. It will be worth it in the end.

Building the Bootstrap Sandbox at the beginning of the course was a really clever way to introduce the entire framework. It has the added side benefit of providing all of the components you need to test if you ever need to customize Bootstrap for a specific project or to conform with your company's brand.

I deducted 1/2 star in my rating is because I don't agree with the way the instructor introduced how to override Bootstrap styles and I wish the Gulp process for building the Bootstrap 4 Starter had been left in the course (and expanded on).

While you can edit the Bootstrap Sass files directly to override styles, Sass variables, and maps, this is not the approach recommended on the Bootstrap 4 site which says "Whenever possible, avoid modifying Bootstrap’s core files. For Sass, that means creating your own stylesheet that imports Bootstrap so you can modify and extend it."  

SOURCE: http://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.1/getting-started/theming/ 

If the course had demonstrated this process, I would have given it 5 stars. 

Regardless, this was my first course with this instructor and I found his teaching style to be focused and engaging. The projects were interesting and thought-provoking. I would (and plan to) complete other courses by Brad Traversy.
results.content_html:
I used Bootstrap 3 extensively and needed to quickly ramp up on Bootstrap 4 in order to start integrating it into work projects and to create a Bootstrap 4 Theme for my employer.

Overall, I enjoyed this course but must admit it was difficult to complete. After completing the third project, the projects started to feel like overkill, but I'm glad I completed them because they are all a bit unique and I can see ways to repurpose them for other learning activities. It felt a lot like practice drills on the piano (e.g. playing scales over and over again). It gets boring, but you develop the necessary muscle memory to use the framework effortlessly. If you are just getting started with the course, keep this in mind and do try to finish all of the projects. It will be worth it in the end.

Building the Bootstrap Sandbox at the beginning of the course was a really clever way to introduce the entire framework. It has the added side benefit of providing all of the components you need to test if you ever need to customize Bootstrap for a specific project or to conform with your company's brand.

I deducted 1/2 star in my rating is because I don't agree with the way the instructor introduced how to override Bootstrap styles and I wish the Gulp process for building the Bootstrap 4 Starter had been left in the course (and expanded on).

While you can edit the Bootstrap Sass files directly to override styles, Sass variables, and maps, this is not the approach recommended on the Bootstrap 4 site which says "Whenever possible, avoid modifying Bootstrap’s core files. For Sass, that means creating your own stylesheet that imports Bootstrap so you can modify and extend it."

SOURCE: http://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.1/getting-started/theming/

If the course had demonstrated this process, I would have given it 5 stars.

Regardless, this was my first course with this instructor and I found his teaching style to be focused and engaging. The projects were interesting and thought-provoking. I would (and plan to) complete other courses by Brad Traversy.

results.content:
EXCELLENT COURSE!!! 5/5, Would Reccomend!!!
I tried taking two other Bootstrap courses; one did not cover enough information to be useful, and the other had such confusing and out-of-correct-order setup instructions for the tools to be used that I had to quit just after I started.
This course was great! I learned enough after the first two projects to build my own website, which is going to help me to move forward with a big project by allowing me to show other people what I'm trying to do just by sharing a link. If you're looking for a comprehensive, easy to follow course in Bootstrap 4, this is it!

results.content:
I don't agree with the way this instructor writes his SASS or his Javascript - they aren't best practices. All the SASS is written in one file and javascript is written inline in the HTML.

I also think he doesn't go into enough detail about the "why" of certain things. Flex layout is a big deal in Bootstrap 4, but very little explanation is given as to why certain practices work. For example, why does margin-right: auto work to push items to the side? I know why, but he doesn't explain.

I've made my way through about half of this course and I'm moving on feeling disappointed. I don't think there's enough good content for me to continue. Sorry, Brad.

results.content:
First of all: Thank you Brad, that you speak clear so that non-native-speaker can understand you easily. 

This is a very profitable and useful course for those who want to become familiar with Bootstrap 4. Especially the new grid-system with flexbox is also new for those who already worked with Bootstrap 3.

Newbies get an idea of npm and gulp for the workflow.

To follow all steps and lessons you need some good skills of HTML and CSS/SASS. And keep in mind: it's always helpful to have the Bootstrap 4 documentation nearby.

Sometimes while watching the videos I was wondering: What is he doing now? And why? So, for me there are two answers:

1. There are always more than one solution to achieve an objective. That's what you can learn in this course.
2. Take the time to code yourself, play around with the code, try different ways, in short: learn by trial and error.

By the way, it's nice to see that an oversight sometimes happens to Brad; mistakes we all make while coding.

I can recommend this course for all the people who want to work as a professional with Bootstrap 4.

results.content:
I am very pleased I to have completed this course. 
It was well set out and enormously comprehensive. 
Mr. Traversy's no-nonsense approach is refreshing.
However, it's difficult to make mistakes following the teacher, 
I am a firm believer that mistakes when learning are a virtue especially with all the resources online to help. 
It’s worth occasionally tinkering with around with some of the code and finding out more about the components that add to Bootstrap (assuming you have no deadline to finish).
All in all, this is a great course. 
I thoroughly recommend it to those mildly or very confident with CSS and HTML.
Cheers and Good Luck.

I am very pleased I to have completed this course.

Mr. Traversy's no-nonsense approach is refreshing.

results.content:
The instructor has a clear accent and a smooth voice, as someone who speaks English as a second language, I found myself understanding 100% of the spoken material. 

The structure of the class seems straightforward, and the provided practice material is well structured. 

I had some personal issues with VS Code itself, but that does not relate to the class - I am using the OSGeo4W framework, and it took me some time to "feed" that highly integrated python build into VS Code - but this isn't a Python course, so this should not matter in any form or way to fellow students, but I plan to use the knowledge handed down here for Flask appliactions mostly.

The project designs at the end seem reasonably convincing, and probably will provide a good concept for building sites for small businesses or freelancers.

in short: I can only recommend this course.

Excellent pace.  The instructor has an outstanding teaching technique. The course is organized in a way that you got to repeat some tasks several times (without being boring), so it helps you to understand the role of each one of the main Bootstrap 4 components, and despite of this, every component is presented.
I would like to see one more project using Bootstrap's "Flex" utility.

One plus for non-native English speakers, like myself: Instructor diction is impeccable. Very easy to follow.

Overall an OK course but I would NOT class this as a beginner course.

results.content:
A good by Brad Traversy. The course starts with an overview of all features added to B4 one by one (sandbox). A good quick reference if required. Then it goes into the application by building some projects.

NOTE: B4 makes broader use of Flexbox and has also moved a lot of CSS into its own classes (margins, font sizes, etc.).

Easy for everyone but better if you already know a bit of B3.

results.content:
The course lacks depth in some areas and you are expected to have some prior knowledge of CSS and HTML. More specifically for CSS, you should know about  (floats, flexbox etc….). In the section on Grid and Flex boxes, he shows you how to call the classes but he does not show you how to use all of them in combination to position objects on a website. That section is pretty much useless unless you go and do your own research on how to use them.  [I have not gotten to the projects.]  

The other modules before that are also just coping the examples from the documentation. 

Because I know myself I'm not giving this a lower score because honestly, I prefer looking through the video than the actual documentation.  

If you are short on money, however, right now I would not recommend this course.  I bought this course alongside another one on how to make web apps hoping that this course would help me be more confident in the front end but right now it's not helping much. 

Suggestion: 
At the end of each section,  combine everything learned in the module to form a website.

results.content: Finishing the 'crash-course' in the beginning going over the new features and code for Bootstrap was great, resourceful and truly helpful with learning. However, with creating a course like this - not everyone is a professional. These different programs we had to install were... Out of the box, unexplored and truly out of mine and possibly someones comfort zone. Especially with using Git Bash to export the css, java and what not - for me that was so hard to follow along and I didn't expect to do something like that straight up with no-less experience in website creation and development. Simplicity is key. The program Atom and Git Bash are so confusing, even when applying the commands and there's an error - how am I supposed to know how to fix it? With a 0 experience course like this, learning code is a good thing, but going through the steps to upload using command, have our own external server, use third party programs to 'export' our work with no idea how to function it? It's not possible, but probably only for me. I'm grateful for the code and the learning of it - but the end of it with the exporting and command promps is not 'Bootstrap 4 From Scratch'.

results.content:
Please note before reading my review:
-I had no experience with bootstrap coming into this course but I do know HTML, CSS, JS, and JQuery.
-Brad rerecorded this course for Bootstrap 4 (beta), so I can't comment on the previous videos.

Positives:
I think the standout feature is the bootstrap sandbox. Brad shows you a variety of classes, what they do and this is done via html templates already set up and provided in the course contents. So, you get to see the before and after when using Bootstrap and that's great. It's also like a cheatsheet for Bootstrap 4, which is brilliant. And by doing 5 projects, you end up having 5 great templates.

Negatives
My biggest negative is that there's definitely a feeling of "I'm literally just copying what he's doing now" and his explanations are lacking. I find this incredibly frustrating with some of the Udemy course instructors, and if you're like me, you will too. That said, you may be different

It is also too fast and you shouldn't have to be playing it at 0.75x or constantly going 15 seconds back or pausing. It disrupts the flow and makes the overall experience less enjoyable.

Do I regret doing this course?
Absolutely not! My understanding of bootstrap is better and I've got a great reference and 5 templates. I just thought it was let down by a few fixable things.

results.content:
You are our Guru, So whatever you teach & taught us is valuable for us. I hope this course will definitely be beneficial for all the beginners, who want their dream to become a Professional Developer. 

How I master this course ?
1. Learn & understand all the components of a website by using bootstrap.
2. Then after studying all the components make our first project with our Guru side by side as he teach us (with more pauses & even breaks).
3. Understand how our guru creates the project using this components of bootstrap and literally copy as a monkey.
4. After copying like a monkey & understanding the concept upto 2 projects, I have started building rest of the projects by my own without watching any video.
5. In rare conditions only we need help by seeing videos rather than just analyze the final project and make to try out building just by seeing the final product.
6. Then only you will learn the fundamentals of bootstrap.

All the best wishes to our Guru, for making this course. Thank you..!

at some points you glossed over some (for me) important details on how you troubleshoot problems. For example during the last resume project you add a media-query and say you had to play around with css to get this to work correctly and I think it would be nice if you would further explain your workflow and HOW you troubleshoot stuff like that. But that is not a complaint on my part, just a suggestion.

Keep up the good work!

results.content:
I enjoyed this course, however it should be mentioned that it's more of a Code-A-Long than anything else. Someone recently asked if I would recommend this course and I said yes, because I believe I learned a great deal. My issue with the course is the lack of clarification and reasoning behind some of the more involved areas. For example I would like to have been told that a carousel NEEDS this specific class but not this other class, and that it'll function differently if you do such and such.

Still overall I'd recommend the course.

results.content:
I came at this course as a programmer with minimal experience in front end web development. I had only minimal experience using HTML and CSS, but feel like these tutorials and explanations have punched my skills up several levels. This was a great introduction. The sandbox tool Brad made is a great reference when I forget something. I appreciate that Brad included a section on setting up a modern workflow using Gulp. I thought that was a valuable and helpful insight into how web developers work.

The ony thing I would have liked to see touched on are design considerations. I don't really have an eye for design and it seems easy, until you try it. It would have been nice to see how/why Brad chose to lay things out the way he did in some of the projects.

results.content: The course is comprehensive, the instructor is easy to follow, the sandbox modules gives students great pages of reference to look back on. Then he shows you how to use everything you've learned with five real-world projects at the end. You will end this class knowing how to construct beautiful pages using Bootstrap 4! Instructor also throws in bonus content on how to use third-party plug-ins, a crash course on npm, SASS and Gulp to make your skills up-to-date as a front end developer. Great class! Well worth your time!

results.content: Giving this course a 4.5 out of 5 because it is very very deep but instructor tends to utilize many more advanced tools (jquery, node.js, git and git bash, etc...) rather than focusing on the topic which is bootstrap.  My guess is he is a very, very talented developer that knows all these other technologies like the back of his hand but I came to learn bootstrap not node.js, jquery, gulp, sass, etc...   The first half of the course can be summarized by your simply typing with instructor while he spends approximately 3 to 5 seconds explaining how the bootstrap function works.   Though this may help some, I would recommend replacing those sections with more in depth details about how to use the most used BS classes (buttons, navbars, cards, grid system, maybe fontawesome video.   The last 5 sections (projects) are fantastic.   Code along with instructor on these and you will learn via his explanations as well repetition the key things in a little more detail via example.  I would not take anything out of this course but I would add some sections that go into more detail of the "why" for topics like Form-groups, Nav-bars, etc... Again maybe just the top 5.  Adding that would allow someone to go from zero to a solid base to begin working with BS.   Thank you to the instructor.  I admit I was super bored with the first 5 sections of just mindless fast coding but the 5 projects more than made up for it.  Thank you so much for this course.

results.content:
I highly recommend this course for people who know basic HTML5 and CSS3 but want to know how to make responsive / mobile-first websites and apps.   
    ** Good example projects with lots of unique styles and functions.
    ** Can take away a basic index.html template and folder template to quick-start your projects.
    ** Some intro to J-query and JavaScript but just enough to get what you need to know and do for each project.
   ** Brad speaks very clearly. I would gladly take another one of his courses.

Heads up:  This course has about 14.5 hours of video, but with taking screenshots and writing notes in MS Word, it actually took me 33.5 hours to complete.

PS:  Folks, don't forget to use the speed modulator if instructors seem to go too fast or slow for you, you can adjust the speed for each video.

results.content:
I thought much more explanation was needed about what each of the many classes specifically does - how each affects the final result. Although the 5 projects provided excellent examples of what can be done with Bootstrap, I would have preferred fewer examples with more elaboration - less typing and more understanding.

I'm a decent typer, but I had trouble keeping up without pausing the video frequently. Additionally, as soon as the final keystrokes in the video were made in a particular set of changes, the view was switched to show the browser or a different piece of code. I could have used a few seconds to just quickly finish typing and match my code to the code in the video. As it was, I had to jump backward 15 seconds constantly and pause the video to accomplish this.

Brad appears to have done much prep for this course and put alot of thought into it, which is appreciated. I did get a great overview of what can be accomplished with Bootstrap and how quickly it can be done.

results.content: Brad is an experienced web developer and has a nice teaching style. He starts with a sandbox where he teaches you all the Bootstrap constructs that you then will apply in 5 projects. All of these projects are websites you will normally encounter in real life. He also shows you some tips and tricks to get your websites looking just that little bit better. In addition, I liked that he left some of his mistakes in the videos as with web design sometimes it is difficult to find the exact reason why something is not working. By showing how he solves the little mistakes, it is easier to backtrack similar ones in your own work. The only thing that I felt was missing is some challenges where you can apply the knowledge learnt on your own. While you get a lot of Bootstrap knowledge out of this course, I feel that having challenges that you need to solve on your own, would have made me even better at Bootstrap. But all in all: thanks Brad!

Basically you won't retain very much. I'd have preferred if there was less content but explained in detail with a look to the style (bootstrap.css); once you mastered the concept and understand how different classes apply different styles in bootstrap, then it's just a matter of class names. 
Also showing the differences of the final result after each line added iot would be nice, since at present you can't understand very well what property does what on the page.
Up to now I would say that a little background of bootstrap is required before diving into this course.

results.content:
Very in-depth for the first part using the sandbox. You get a nice overview of what's possible with bootstrap even though some explanation as to the WHY of certain things would have been welcome.

The second part where you have to install a slew of various programs and modules was weaker. I found myself wondering out loud "why am I doing all this?", and never really got a satysfying answer.
For a while, I just ran with it, but then I realised I would have to do a lot of searching on my own to get a grasp of what's happening.

You do a lot of thorough HTML/CSS/JS for a few hours, then out of nowhere, with no real explanations of what are SASS, GULP, NPM, Node.js, etc. you just type in blindly what is asked without understanding what it is you're doing.

For people with more experience in Web development, this might be perfect. For someone who's been learning all of this for a little under a year, it is a little intense. I'm all for adding skills to my budding arsenal, but I want to know why.

Still, the first part is well done with a lot of nice examples and can stand on its own as a bootstrap reference.

results.content: There are a lot of updates to Bootstrap 4 and FontAwesome. You should probably redo this entire project (Mizuxe) with updated libraries. results.content:
I'm mostly a back-end programmer but have been muddling through with a couple of front-end projects using Bootstrap since version 2. This course helped me realize that some of the chronic problems I was having were due to not using the framework properly. With the previous versions I spent lots of time trying to figure things out on my own with mixed results. I am hopeful that the investment I made in time taking this course will pay off in my being more productive right away without spinning my wheels like I usually do.

The instructor did a good job. I would have liked more theory with "why" and "how" explanations to go along with material, but I could always pause and look things up when I needed to.

results.content: This course wasn't good... it was excellent. Brad Traversy has a great instructional style, I've appreciated this in previous courses and videos. To be honest, simply ploughing through all the Bootstrap classes then applying them to projects was always going to be a bit of a labour but it has been structured very well, firstly with everything in the sandbox, then on to practical application within the projects. For a high quality, solid foundation in the understanding and use of Bootstrap4, this is as good as it gets. THOROUGHLY RECOMMENDED.

results.content:
I found Brad from his YouTube channel when I was first learning web development. After browsing through his free content on YouTube, I knew pretty quickly that I really liked his teaching style and decided to purchase all of his courses available on Udemy. This is the second one I've completed, the first being the HTML & CSS course. I already had a pretty strong grasp on both basic HTML & CSS and bootstrap, but decided that a refresher wouldn't be a bad idea. After taking both courses, I can say wholeheartedly, I learned information that I did not already know and am much more confident in my ability with these skills. 

Thank you so much Brad for your tremendous work and I can't wait to take the rest of your courses!

results.content:
Course structure is simple and clear. First use the sandbox (it comes to turely handy when you build your own project.) to explain how it works, after then take you step by step to build five common project. This all helps me to learn Bootstrap efficiently form the start to end.

Followed Brad form his youtube channel to here. Thank him for designing these courses, and spending time to make sure the content up to date.

課程架構簡單易懂。 從使用設計的沙盒（之後自己製作專案時非常好用）分區塊介紹Bootstrap的各個項目，再到一步步帶你完成五個常見的應用。 這些都讓我從頭到尾毫無壓力的學習Bootstrap。

results.content:
First of all, I would not recommend this course to a beginner in Bootstrap 4 / HTML / CSS! If you want to learn basic HTML/CSS or learn about each Bootstrap component more in-depth (do exercises with each module), you will find better courses on Udemy.

Now, why did I give this course a 5/5 Star?
This course consists of two sections:
The Sandbox Section and the Projects Section.

The Sandbox Section is basically an overview of all the Bootstrap 4 components that are used in the Projects Section. These are small HTML/CSS sections that show how each component and class is being used and it gives the student an opportunity to try them all out in a HTML sandbox that Brad shows how to build early. These sections aren't as detailed as one might hope and they don't include any exercises whatsoever. The instructor breezes through these sections quickly. 

The Projects Section includes 5 different projects that include techniques, which can applied in real world front-end projects. To me, this was the highlight of the course and I really enjoyed going through each project. They are well designed and thought out and would look great on anyone's portfolio. Most projects involve using third party JavaScript and CSS files files to extend bootstrap functionalities and components. These were really fun to work with and the results were very eye catching.

Other than that the course has some sections on customizing your Bootstrap front-end using SASS and shows you how to build a reliable boilerplate code that you can use in your future Bootstrap projects.

The instructor starts out by going straight to the point (definitely doesn't try to waste your time), speaks clearly and gives accurate instructions.  He does each section live, so when he runs into problems him self, he shows you how he fixed them.

All in all the course is excellent and I would recommend it to anyone, who would like to to delve deeper into Bootstrap 4 and wants to build usable web based user interfaces or websites.

results.content:
In the first section, Brad introduces the features through practice exercises and by the end of the features walkthrough; we are left with a great cheat sheet that can be referred back to at any time.

The next section focuses on 5 projects which all look good and really reinforce the features of bootstrap that were learned in the previous section.

By the end of the course, I feel comfortable enough with Bootstrap to look at a design mockup and code it within a few hours.

The only slight con I have is that the explanations as to what each class exactly is doing is scattered throughout the course or not mentioned. But this con isn't that bad because just by sheer practice and scope of each project, we can pretty much deduce what is happening behind the scenes.

results.content: This is a great course! The instructor goes fairly quick when coding the demo sites, so I had to pause quite a bit, but I appreciate the instructor not taking so long in explanations. Other instructors seem to waste time by going over things in extreme redundancy. The fact that I have the sandbox to go back to for my "notes" is an excellent way of pairing the sandbox with the demo sites together. If I forget an application of Bootstrap, all I have to do is go back to my "notes" to familiarize myself with concepts I may have forgotten. A+ for this course!

results.content:
I signed up for this course as soon as I heard it was available. I have done other courses by Brad Traversy from Eduonix and have been following his YouTube channel for months now. His content is first-rate: up-to-date, relevant, concise yet comprehensive, practical but with enough depth to understand the technology and be able to put it to use. His teaching style is ideal for me: informal yet professional, warm and engaging; the pace is brisk but unhurried. 

If I could sum up this Bootstrap 4 From Scratch course in one word it would be PRAXIS - the student learns by doing. The first part is an overview and tour of Bootstrap and the key features of version 4 with demonstrations delivered using a cool custom-built sandbox feature. The second part is code-along projects that guides the student through setting up a development environment (and learning some really cool tricks using Gulp, Sass and NPM to boot) and then using it as a foundation for the main projects. At the end I feel that I have a much better grasp of Bootstrap 4 and some great tools and resources to use moving forward.

results.content:
Splitting the course between "Sandbox Demonstration" and "Code-along projects" was really brilliant. While I'm working on personal bootstrap projects outside of the course now, I'll come back and refer to specific sandbox videos to refresh myself on things like "how much margin should I add?" or "what should I use to align things?"

The projects are really clever too, in how they utilize all the big Bootstrap concepts and elements. It's great seeing how Bootstrap works in action, but also I really appreciate the ideas that the mock-sites gave me for my own personal designs.

Overall really clever, helpful, and intuitive.

results.content:
This is one of the best courses for learning Bootstrap 4 that I have taken. The first part of the course is the sandbox, which is a series of lessons on how Bootstrap works. You get the blank template files and the final files, so you can code along with Brad, and if you get stuck, you have the finished file on your hard drive to see where you went wrong.

The five projects were interesting, and I appreciated that they were different so I could learn different ways of building sites with Bootstrap. 

I've got 2 other courses from Brad to get to, and I can't wait. He's a good instructor, and I learned a lot. Thanks Brad.

results.content:
Incredibly well done. I can't say enough good things. So easy to understand and follow. Make sure you go through each section including building the sandbox and reference sections - it really helps connect how Bootstrap really works. 

Best part about this is that the course doesn't just stop at show how the framework can be used but actually implementing it into projects with popular modern trending features. For example... try searching on how to make a responsive navbar on Google. Now good luck filtering. With these projects it covers it so well!

Doesn't stop there... Brad actually takes you into building your own production environment through Node.js; awesome!

I'm on project 2 and loving it. Well done Brad! Looking forward to more of your work!

results.content: Great course. It really takes you from knowing nothing about bootstrap to becoming pretty fluent. Of course it doesn't make you an expert, that comes with experience. But this course will help you become adept at Bootstrap 4. Love the sandbox because I can refer back to it whenever I need to. There are a ton of classes to know and understand so having the sandbox is a great visual to have if I ever get stuck.  The teacher also shows multiple shortcuts while using your preferred text editor so that's extremely helpful when it comes to speeding up workflow.  I also like how the course isn't planned out from start to finish. The teacher makes multiple mistakes throughout the course and I like this because it gives insight on how web developers work and proves that nobody, not even a fully seasoned web dev, is perfect. This course does require you to have knowledge in HTML and CSS but I hope nobody is trying to learn Bootstrap without first having a firm grasp on those languages lol Overall, I highly recommend this course to anybody trying to learn Bootstrap 4. I've already enrolled in his Javascript course. Well done teacher!

results.content:
Don't generally comment on Udemy offerings but had to for this excellent course by Brad Traversy. The initial exhaustive walk through is a wonderful precursor to the projects. By design, Brad is forcing the viewer (passive observer or active coder) to internalize the breadth and depth of Bootstrap ahead of "real work" on the projects. This early phase is the "WHAT".  This methodology results in a much richer understanding of the material as we execute on the projects. This is the "HOW".

Well done, Brad, for having deep expertise in the material but also in your clear, patient exposition. I learned a lot!

results.content: I liked the sandbox in the beginning that goes over all the major features of bootstrap; it's good practice and helps some of those classes really stick! Then, putting it all together by building different projects was awesome! I was able to complete the projects using bootstrap 5 while it was in beta. The only thing that I couldn't get to work was the lightbox, which is no big deal because I'm sure I can find a way to implement that feature somehow. If you're completely new, stick with the provided course files/boilerplate for bootstrap 4 and you should be fine! Some things in bootstrap 5 have changed, but it's totally doable if you look at the documentation to see what's different when going over each subject, such as cards, modals, forms, etc... This was a great course and I'm sure I will be referring back to it as I start to practice building some of my own projects!

results.content:
Brad is a fantastic instructor! I'm really enjoying his courses here and on YouTube, and I'm learning a ton.

He explains everything very clearly, and his pacing moving between code and browser helps keep you from getting too far down the road before catching an error.

Repetition is important while learning, and he manages to repeat concepts while providing a new twist each time, introducing you gradually to useful libraries along the way. Perfect.

Brad is also really personable, and I've noticed that he is inclusive when creating sample data, which is respectable as well as respectful. Kudos for that, Brad, and thank you for these courses!

results.content: This course gave me exactly what I needed to better grasp Bootstrap. Thanks, Brad! I've used it for a few projects here and there, but I have a much clearer understanding of what it can do (and what it can't). I ran into some issues with some of the classes here and there (I can't help but to make the projects my own) but it was helpful in understanding the limitations of Bootstrap. I suggest to anyone taking this course - code along - but then experiment with what you can do!

results.content:
This could be a terrific course, if only the instructor would give more explanation on basic things around using the Terminal. Even though he says in the beginning that it won't be used much, it is still crucial for evolving in the course. I got very stuck halfway through, due to errors on the command line, since instructor's Windows workflow doesn't always translate so well onto Mac OS. So the process becomes very glitchy and hampers a smooth moving forward after first half of the course.
Overall, the instructor does take you through the "grinding" of writing code through repetition, which helps you memorise it better, and it seems to be a good way to learn Bootstrap from the very ground. But if you're a beginner, you might have to do some digging before you make the ground itself. I.e. look-up Node.js and how to work with the Terminal if these things mean nothing to you.
The projects part (second half of the course) is however really worthwhile, and I came to understand more about bootstrap and node; it's also great for building a portfolio, you can adapt the templates to your versions if you want, and overall the course gets you going with web development work!

results.content: The course is very in depth with detailed explanations on the various Bootstrap CSS and JS widgets and modules. I think to make it that much better is to provide students with some tasks to complete in between sections, rather than copying from the lecturer throughout the course. Giving people like me an opportunity to put what I have learned into action on a smaller side-project with minimal guidance would help people like me improve further on their Bootstrap knowledge.

results.content:
So far, so good. The first part seems like a good, quick overview of bootstrap basics. The instructor is easy to listen to and understand, and the examples are clear. I particularly like the fact that most of the HTML markup and content has been entered for us so boring, repetitive typing is kept to a minimum.

Partway through the first project, I'm still keeping up and (mostly) able to understand the material. Creation of the Bootstrap 4 Starter Pack (Beta 4.0.0), though complex, turned out to be dead-simple to do because it was well and clearly explained. And vital; I plan to use the Starter Pack to jump-start every web project I undertake from now on.

The HTML and CSS code is straightforward and the instructor seems dead-set on not losing any of his students. The biggest problem is that Bootstrap has so many classes with so many dependencies and connections, that I can't imagine being able to remember which classes to use for what. But I'm still plugging along and hoping for the best.

I'm done with the course. Really liked it! The first part laid a solid foundation and the second, the projects part, brought it all together for me. I learned stuff! I'm reasonably certain I could build a solid website now, with only Google and my course notes to guide me. It wouldn't be a "real" website, because I don't yet know how to build a back-end database or how to connect the back end to my front end with an appropriate programming language.

But hey ... one thing at a time, right? I'm not sure which educational challenge to tackle next but I'll probably start my search with Udemy.

Brad, thanks for an excellent course.

results.content:
This was a super good course on what you can do with Bootstrap 4. The 5 demo projects you code are very diverse and will show you various aspects of how to design and code a website from which you then can continue.

While doing the course I only thought of 2 things which in my opinion could have improved the learning experience

- Provide challenges. Show the students a design and teach them how they could approach implementing it.  
- Show some more of your insights, let them participate in your thought process. Tell students why you solved certain designs the way that you did. Like this the students could benefit more  of your gained experience

All in all a very good course which I only can recommend.

It's really good and hep me on some section to upgrade my skills. Thanks for all your effort to make those projects but I found an issue on one of your project which you need to look once.


The Mizuxe Book Theme:

Point no 50. on the Authors Area.

You set your icon color to white. which was an error. You should put that on hover effect. So basically it should be your primary color and when you hover on it, it will be white.

Let me know if you got my point or not.

Thanks again for all your efforts on us.

results.content:
I think Brad's exercise files are great but the biggest issue with this course is that he doesn't really explain anything. He just types as you follow along and he might mention why he is doing something or what changes occur but doesn't really explain the different types of bootstrap functions.

Basically, it's nice to follow along but if you want to actually learn bootstrap, another course would probably be much better if you want to actually understand and know about bootstrap instead of just following along without really gaining any insight into the why.

results.content:
I am currently at section 4 while writing this review. 

The instructor is very vague. He just types a bunch of code and says all the names of the classes out loud, and then says, after a chunk of code being saved and showing the result, "And then you get this". 

I would rather see him save the code after every class change so I see what everything he does changes in the web page. It does not need a big explenation. But I have no idea, for example, what of the 30 classes in the div caused the card example to have what effect and why certain classes were even needed in the first place.

I like your voice, you are very clear. And perhaps in the future sections I will feel different, but for now it feels like a vague vocal documentation, and looking at the original price of the course (150 euros), I would not recommend it. But, if you can get it (as I did) for 12 euros, its well worth the price. 

I would like to see the improvement. But again, I am not finished, and maybe in the future I  will feel more of a connection to the course.

results.content:
This course is in two sections; the bootstrap components and examples of projects using bootstrap. The course is comprehensive and detailed. I will use it more of a reference than following through the sections from start to finish. I think this course was a good purchase and recommend it.

The course includes html files demonstrating all the styles and components in bootstrap. I am finding this very useful as a reference.

I found the course long winded in places. Having been shown what button classes do and what colour classes do I don't need to see every combination. Having seen a blue button I can imagine what other coloured buttons look like without having to see the html typed in. Showing every combination adds a lot of minutes.

The course concentrates on the code but sometimes some comments on why / the intent would be beneficial. For example I learn't how to create an active button .. but why would you want to use one? What use case is it supposed to solve?

results.content: Overall, I have to agree with the other negative reviews. The instructor may be knowledgeable, but he doesn't spend much time explaining why he does things. As others have said, it's not so much a course as it's a rushed set of type-along-with-the-instructor videos. It's also concerning to see him violate best practices, like editing Bootstrap source files directly rather than overriding the values in his own SCSS file. I'm new to Bootstrap, but this was a HUGE red flag when I saw this. A quick Google search confirmed it's not the recommended way to change the Bootstrap defaults. It also didn't seem like he put much effort into the Sass file layout or following best practices. I can only assume the 4 and 5 star reviews are from people who either know Bootstrap 3 well and just want a quick primer on Bootstrap 4, or they're people who are new to HTML and Sass and don't know or care about these things.

results.content: Great course for people having issues learning bootstrap. Brad explains all the concepts thoroughly, provides tons of classes and the templates provided within bootstrap as part of a sandbox so you can reference them later when you're working on projects solo. He also has walkthroughs of five separate projects, incorporating a couple cool, simple addons as well. Helped me immensely learn more about bootstrap and how to structure a webpage with it. I'll never forget .container and .row again lol

results.content: If you're looking for a quick way to learn the fundamentals of Bootstrap without trawling the internet and miserably failing with snippets of code that are 6 months old and rarely work properly anyway, then I urge you to buy this course. I'm not the brightest bulb in the pack, but Brad's teaching style is so easy to follow and well-explained that even I quickly found myself ploughing through the videos like there was no tomorrow :) A bonus is that he shows you how to quickly set up and start your own project using Git Bash and NPM. You'll be knocking up Bootstrap themes in no time!

results.content:
A very helpful course! The first section is a comprehensive overview of the Bootstrap 4 Beta classes and what each of them does.  The rest of the course consists of projects in which we get to put those classes to use.

The repetition of building not just one project, but five projects, is incredibly valuable.  Using the techniques over and over again in different ways helps them sink in. Plus, you end up with several projects you can add to your portfolio by the end.

The one thing I found myself wishing for during the course was for Brad (the instructor) to toggle back and forth between the code and the finished product more frequently. Sometimes he does a long block of code before finally toggling over to view the results, which makes it harder to understand what each piece of code accomplished.  (I did toggle over on my own from time to time, but it would have been helpful to have an explanation from the instructor on this as we went.)

Overall, great course!  Highly recommended!

results.content: First half of the course is a detailed and extremely thorough explanation of Bootstrap 4; you will definitely understand what Bootstrap 4 can do. The course examples are nearly identical to the Bootstrap 4 Documentation. Learning would be increased if the video showed you how to do something, and then you had to do it on your own, instead of just adding classes to already existing HTML. Second half of the course is applying the Bootstrap 4 knowledge through code-along projects. The projects are excellent for re-enforcing concepts gained in the first 1/2 of the course. Explanations are crystal clear and your ability to use Bootstap 4 quickly accelerates, especially if you play the video, and then try it yourself, and then compare your code to the final code to determine errors. Fabulous course!

results.content:
Just Finished the Course.
Update :  I changed my rating from originally 1/2 star to 4 stars and this is because the course becomes beautiful  more engaging and more informative when reaching the projects. I did not knew about gulp and sass and I managed to learn the basics from just couple of videos - that is the way I like the explanation to be in this course.  Overall, it is good course but could be a lot better. Nevertheless I can say I have learned new stuff definitely. The instructor is knowledgeable and he seems he has created a lot of templates before.  Please see below for the critical part of my review: 

Critical Review of sandbox sections: 
The sandbox sections are just a laundry list , in some cases, no useful explanation whatsoever of the Bootstrap classes or the problems that these CSS classes are trying to solve. A bunch of things (divs, paragraphs etc..) on the  sandbox, and the instructor is applying a laundry list of classes from bootstrap to them.  What was annoying to me is that you feel he is copying them from a paper or editor in front of him in monotone way. No explanation to why we have this margin per example. Why this needs a data-toggle attribute etc... It is like he is showcasing to you what Bootstrap can do; not why it do it the way it do it and more important how you can change the default  behavior. Although to be fair He tackled  that later quite quickly when he showed how to change one of SCSS (SASS) files of Bootstrap itself.
Another example, he did not explain 'clearfix' class, why it is needed? and what is the problem here? - I had to read some stackoverflow answers to understand more. Things of this sort.
The instructor also has an extremely annoying tendency of assigning like over 50 classes (without explaining them) to like 50 elements and then refreshing the page to let you see the result. As if we are supposed to understand the 'aggregate effect' of all CSS classes used, instead of showing what each class is doing really, this can be seen  when he was explaining the nav bar, the forms among many many others.... It is ok if the course is 1 hour longer and this is taken into account!!!
The Atom editor is pretty dark. Please put the editor on clear light themes, this is because  it is on a screen cast  and the majority of people view the course on mobile devices. It burns your eyes especially on mobile and tablets!
