Not an easy recommend. It's clear that mr. Traversy knowns his trade and he is responsive to questions in the Q&A section, however there are some glaring issues with this course:

- no challenges; everything, every website, is spoon-fed to you;
- usage of bad practices in development (i.e.: editing the library file variables directly instead of overwriting them in your own files; using multiple variable naming conventions in the same file (likeThis and-like-this));
- errors sometimes in the code; sections sometimes already completed; a lot of copy/paste work in the beginning; websites sometimes do not look right on some breakpoints but are omitted;
- a lot of the navbar code in the example websites is the same; no experimenting with more complex/different navbars (i.e.: all example websites created only with horizontal responsive navbar, no side navbar);

I will say this; the cheat sheet files created in the first five sections is a nice-to-have structure for future reference and, while the sections were repetitive, it can be of use in the future.

Mr. Traversy states in the beginning that he has hurried to release this course and that (at time of recording) it is the only course using Bootstrap 4 beta, and I believe him. It feels rushed. Ironically, at the time of writing, Boostrap 4 stable has been released.

If you are experienced in the web industry (or at least development) you can learn things from this course. If you are planning to start from scratch, however, at the end you will only have 5 pretty sites with little understanding as to how you got here and perhaps even pick up some bad habits along the way.

results.content:
I've taken a few courses about HTML/CSS/JS before. This course was the next inline. I don't think my other courses were bad either, but I discovered that Brad's way of teaching by providing a Sandbox environment and going through every major part one by one in a methodological way was just the thing I was looking for. 

When you're a newbie you have no idea what is in your toolbox and how to use them. He shows you every piece like "This is a nail, this is a screw driver, this is a saw, etc." By the end of the Sandbox section, you will have solid idea what you can create with your new tools.

In the project section he will show you how to use these tools in a more complex manner, and you will build 5 real world oriented projects.

I think the effort he made to put together a course like this is admirable.

results.content: I learnt everything I need to start working on my own Bootstrap themes. The sandbox is an excellent reference for when you need a quick refresher on certain classes and concepts. The course was really enjoyable, and I highly recommend it to anyone who is confused about what Boostrap is and how to use it. I always get anxious when it comes to building frontends, but now that anxiety is gone! I will be able to talk Bootstrap with the best of them. I think the highlight of this course, for me, was learning a bit about Sass. And I have also been introduced to a world of JavaScript plugins, which I can't wait to explore and find out what else is out there. Lastly, I'd recommend this course because he just doesn't do something and show you that it works, but he also explains the why and how of it.

results.content: This is an awesome class. I have now completed it and I have truly enjoyed it. The only reason that I have given it less than 5 stars (which I rarely give 5 stars) is that he is very fast and you don't have time to type anything in before he is on to the next piece. He really knows his stuff and it makes it very hard to continue. I would suggest really paying attention to the Sandbox as that it the REAL learning piece and the sites/applications are a bonus to put your learning into play and to drill it into your mind. He goes into depth on what things do in the Sandbox but not as much in the others. I also suggest using Pause A LOT. Pause, Pause, Pause but that is easy to do. Overall a great course to learn Bootstrap and CSS and to drill it in a bit if you truly want to learn it.

results.content: I would absolutely give this a 5 star, but I really think there should have been at least one lesson on setting up node-sass using npm instead of koala.  There probably needs to be a better ending to the course.  One lesson just summing up what was covered and where a student can go from here.  At least more of a congratulations and a very short road map on where to go with the new bootstrap skills.  Like building your own cheet sheet using bootstrap for bootstrap 4.  Also, sometimes when Brad gets moving along, he forgets that a lot of people are watching his code, and he'll zoom out of the editor the instant he is finished and check the live-server, all before the student can hit the pause button and see what code he just finished entering.  Maybe worth an extra beat or two before leaving the editor.  Brad is an excellent teacher.  His temperament is perfect for a teacher.  He has mastery of the material, and he's gifted at conveying that so others can learn from him.  He's born to teach, it seems to me.  Naturally empathetic and patient and encouraging.  The world can really use lots more like him.

results.content:
The course covers everything a person may need to know to use Bootstrap4 confidently. There is a good range of projects that can easily be used as templates for personal projects. Explanations of what each class and decision made is very clear. The sandbox idea is genius and probably enough to start any developer off using Bootstrap4 - The projects are like icing on the cake to solidify the knowledge developed in the sandbox using a variety of the concepts covered.  There is one consideration I would recommend - larger screen users (especially with larger screens becoming more and more popular), some of the sections become a little distorted at full resolutions. There is also a moment at the end of the 'Glozzum' section where you note that the lightbox images on small screens create a scrolling-bar and the images are not resized to fit the screen size - it would be really nice if you added a short video on how to get this to work.
Overall thanks Brad I have certainly learned a lot from this course!

results.content:
This course is definitely in-depth and also goes hands on on almost -if not all- everything you'll need to know about Bootstrap 4. Of course, as expected, it's nowhere near to get you ready to apply for any job requiring Bootstrap. That ability comes with tons of practice. The instructor was on point and was explaining everything. Maybe i'd like a little more explanation, but that's me. As mentioned in the requirements before I bought the course, basic HTML and CSS knowledge is required. Maybe a bit more than basic. There were also some jQuery parts but nothing too hard or nothing that was left unexplained. Also, at first I thought that the projects were going to be more like exercises and without the complete guidance of the instructor, but that wasn't the case. So, the only thing i found was lacking, was maybe a set of practice exercises at the end of the course.

Easily recommending this course to anyone who not only has X amount of money to pay and wants to learn Bootstrap, but also to those who are consciously interested in investing their money and more important, time, to master it. 

Kudos Brad.

results.content:
I am not a harsh critic of Udemy courses generally, but this one was so awful, I had to stop everything and just write how bad the course really is.
My biggest complaint is that this course really feels like a reference book on video, with a, what he calls a sandbox, to experiment on. It totally takes the Boostrap classes out of context! Bootstrap is supposed to style a website.. it's not supposed to be learned in isolation over some 'learning' page. Imagine you're training for football ALONE: you learn to kick the ball, to run, etc. ... yes you will learn something, but how will you play in a football game WITH OTHER PLAYERS? Similarly, display classes, float classes, are all part of a bigger thing called a website. How would one go about using these in the context of a website.

Look, I know there are projects included at the end, but I will be VERY surprised if someone could trudge through the course to reach the projects. The initial sections are tedious, long-winded, and REALLY feel like a reference book on video.

If I wanted to learn like this, I would have picked up a pdf cheat sheet online somewhere.

I am sorry, but this course was poorly taught, boring, and tedious.

results.content:
This is the best, most current course on Bootstrap currently available on Udemy (or anywhere else I've been able to find).
The instructor not only takes you step-by-step on how to set up Bootstrap 4 beta on your computer, he explains how to use the features you'll probably use every day as a developer.

Honestly, it was worth the price of the course just to get his starter pack. It gives you a great way to set your projects up uniformly every time.

If you want to learn to use the most current iteration of Bootstrap, I can't urge you strongly enough to take this course.

results.content:
Still working thru the course - it is absolutely fantastic. The work Brad has done to organize the content in the downloadable pages (sandbox) from which one can quickly develop beautiful content.

I can also appreciate the little errors and corrections Brad goes thru. He does explain how this is an example of keeping it real and I agree. i.e. instead of editing out every little issue or typing mistake, to create a slick error free presentation, he will make some mistakes, or determine a better way of doing things, undo some of the work just done, or fix an issue, and move on. This is good, this is how work gets done in the real world. We often stop development, read up at the site of the technology provider like Apache, jQuery or Bootstrap, learn a few things, post a question on Stackoverflow.com and get work done. This is perfectly OK.

My only regret is that I didn't pay full price for the course - he deserves it!  I did buy the Python/Django and Node, will get a couple more courses from TraversyMedia.

Will update this review when I complete the source.

results.content:
Got this course out of curiosity. Personally I would still prefer to design from scratch if I had the choice between that or using bootstrap - but I guess I can see how it can be helpful for certain types of developers/projects. Regardless it was interesting to check this course out and learn how it works.

As far as the teaching method here... I sometimes found myself frustrated during times when I wished the instructor would give play-by-play explanations for what he was doing. Would be better if he broke it down a little more to help the student visualize how each line of code affects the component being built instead of just writing entire blocks of code and only showing the final component without explaining how each of the parts work together. I already had a strong understanding of css (including grid&flex systems)/scss/automating dev environments going into this course so it wasn't hard for me to follow for the most part, but I think if I did not have that level of knowledge already... a lot of the stuff here would have been confusing simply because the "why" isn't explained enough in detail. 

This course does offer several project themes for you to code along and build to gain practice with Bootstrap, but the course flow is pretty much just "watch and copy what I do". Don't expect to have a detailed explanation for everything that is done here. Overall it's a decent course if you're just generally curious about Bootstrap.

results.content:
The course is decent, but there is not enough explanations concerning WHY you're writing what the instructor says. For instance, the course in no ways covers what "flexbox" actually is and what it means, it only tells you to use it here and there without really explaining what it'll do other than you seeing the end result. I would have preferred some more explanations of the concepts being used rather than the more "monkey see, monkey do" approach used in this course. It's still a usefull, obviously, but it leaves out key information that you'll have to seek out on your own to get explained. 

One rather significant minus is that the course covers the Bootstrap 4 Beta, and there are quite a few differences between that end the final release. Since the course always uses the beta version even if a new one is available though, it doesn't break the examples, but it will break if you update to the current version. Since the BS4 final is just a few weeks old, I haven't really let this affect my overall as I'm hoping the course will be updated, although no course updates in 6 months doesn't really fill me with confidence in that regard.

results.content:
I recommend this course to everyone who wants to learn about bootstrap. At the beginning of the course you receive a very handy "cheatsheet", which is truly awesome and with that you can build almost anything. The instructor is very clear and you can see that he has put A LOT of effort for this course! Two thumbs up!

The only problem was that towards the end of the course the pace was a little bit too fast and it became more about copying the code and not explaining and understanding things.. so I am not sure if I am right away able to make projects that look like my own rather than looking almost like the same. I do realize that things were explained in the beginning of the course but repeating the same things as a sidenote at least never hurt anyone.

Anyway, great course and I really appreciate the effort that was put into this and all the projects as well!

results.content:
I learned some bootcamp in a 'full stack' course, but I needed it broken down to the specifics a little bit better. It was nice to code along projects with someone, so a new coder like me can get a feel for the workflow. All my questions received a response, and I signed up for Brad's JavaScript class. 

I recommend this class for someone who knows what they want to get out of Bootstrap, and wants to see how most of its features are actually implemented.

results.content:
Ich habe den Kurs ausgewählt, weil ich einen Überblick zu und praxisorientierten Einstieg in Bootstrap 4 haben wollte. Außerdem kannte ich Brads Stil von Videos aus seinem Youtube-Channel. Er ist außerordentlich gut zu verstehen und hat eine sehr angenehme Stimmlage.
Der Kurs hat mich auf der ganzen Linie überzeugt. Ein besonderes Highlight ist die Bootstrap Sandbox, die als "Nachschlagewerk" immer wieder und vor allen Dingen schnell genutzt werden kann.
Die Projektseiten sind sehr gut gewählt, greifen verschiedene aktuelle Designelemente auf und zeigen, wie sie allein schon mit Bootstrap umgesetzt werden können. Back End Developer finden hier auch ein Webprojekt, das sich als Ausgangspunkt für eigene Projekte gut nutzen lässt.
Für mich war noch der Exkurs zur individuellen Anpassung von Bootstrap mit SASS besonders interessant (Stichwort Farbschema!). Dazu hätte ich mir ein ausführlicheres Beispiel zum Theming gewünscht. Aber es ist kein Kurs zu Webdesign und das Beispiel reicht für den Einstieg vollkommen aus.
5 Sterne gibt es auch, weil sich Brad nicht nur auf Bootstrapelemente beschränkt, sondern an passender Stelle noch zeigt, wie mit ein wenig Hilfe von etwas JavaScript Code und externen "Bibliotheken" z.B. Smooth Scrolling, Slider, eine Lightbox und Texteditoren eingebaut werden können.

Der Kurs hat mich auf der ganzen Linie überzeugt. Ein besonderes Highlight ist die Bootstrap Sandbox, die als "Nachschlagewerk" immer wieder und vor allen Dingen schnell genutzt werden kann.
Die Projektseiten sind sehr gut gewählt, greifen verschiedene aktuelle Designelemente auf und zeigen, wie sie allein schon mit Bootstrap umgesetzt werden können. Back End Developer finden hier auch ein Webprojekt, das sich als Ausgangspunkt für eigene Projekte gut nutzen lässt.
Für mich war noch der Exkurs zur individuellen Anpassung von Bootstrap mit SASS besonders interessant (Stichwort Farbschema!). Dazu hätte ich mir ein ausführlicheres Beispiel zum Theming gewünscht. Aber es ist kein Kurs zu Webdesign und das Beispiel reicht für den Einstieg vollkommen aus.
5 Sterne gibt es auch, weil sich Brad nicht nur auf Bootstrapelemente beschränkt, sondern an passender Stelle noch zeigt, wie mit ein wenig Hilfe von etwas JavaScript Code und externen "Bibliotheken" z.B. Smooth Scrolling, Slider, eine Lightbox und Texteditoren eingebaut werden können.

results.content:
WHO IS THIS COURSE FOR?
Did the first 46% (the 'sandbox' part) of the course. The teacher knows his bootstrap stuff but while he's typing he forgets to teach. Most of the time he's isn't explaining anything. He's just doing his 'code along' without talking about the reasons why he's doing things and what his actions mean. In the intro of his course, the teacher clearly states you do not have to know anything about bootstrap. Well, his way of teaching does not relate to that statement. Most of the bootstrap classes and attributes he uses aren't explained at all, which makes listening a wast of time.

UPDATE:
49% Now I'm at the second part of the course. In this part he will be building projects. I still wanna give it a chance cause I hope things will get better en more clear.
Unfortunately also the section about the Gulp task-manager which contains a coded automation of processes has no explanation. Which means you're learning nothing an above all hardly know what you are doing when typing his code into your own file. 

UPDATE: 
First project (LoopLAB) - Again the teaching is going like this: "Now we need a div with a class of collapse and navbar-collapse". 
Unfortunately, there's no explanation of what these classes do. What is the function or the effect of the class 'collapse' or 'navbar-collapse'. The instructor really does not explain the working of those (and almost  every other class) classes anywhere in the course. He's just telling and not teaching. Reading through the Bootstrap documentation will get you just as far, probably further. 

Also is he exactly doing as expected. Not explaining classes in the 'Sandbox' section, and now referring to this supposed explanation. Pretty annoying....  

The question remains. WHO IS THIS COURSE FOR? It is certainly not a beginner course. But also not advanced. I mean an advanced  bootstrap user would not take this course cause it is much to basic. This is just a do as I do course. No teaching, just a code along.

When the content improves I will add some extra comments and stars. Without addition to this comment, unfortunately nothing changed....

results.content:
Brad is a good teacher. The Sandbox sessions were a weird mix of completely frustrating and 100% helpful so I would completely recommend persevering through them - repetition is helpful. 
As things progressed I felt like I was rushing to keep up and pausing a lot which took away from allowing things to absorb. 
Things went at a lightning pace (which without the sandbox sessions one would be utterly lost) in the projects and I'd have like just a bit more time between writing lines of code to keep up - additionally it would help let the concepts sink in. I don't want to just code-along, that's easy. I want to code-along for the sake of understanding.
So, instead of getting to a point where we might want to have a look at the live server (Brad gets to these sections and says "Ok, lets save and have a look" and then just like that the screen with VS Code is gone and Im looking at the thing that I'm trying to do which means I have to go back and forth in the video timeline. 
I personally do best when we get to the end of a section and the instructor gives a brief overview of what we just did and why we did it - it doesn't have to be long -- just 10 seconds or even less. That way I A) Get a better grasp of the reasons we've coded something up the way we did, and B) have a bit of extra time to keep up with the pace. 

That said, the projects gave a great overview of the power of Bootstrap.

results.content:
This is the second course I have taken with Brad, so I knew going in what to expect.
Pros- Well paced courses with a lot of information and a lot of actual useful projects as opposed to just theory
Cons- Brad could do a better job in walking students through not just the projects that he has put together, but how to understand the process of design, what are the factors in creating clean/user friendly experiences, and more focus on capturing variables and how the nesting structure works.

Overall, if you need an intro to Bootstrap, this is a solid course to take.

results.content:
Brad creates content that is enlightening and useful for real world applications. This course will provide you with the tools to sit down and create any Front-End project with Bootstrap on your own.

The sand-box content alone is worth the money as Brad has delivered to us the full content of the Bootstrap "lingo" so you can look things up with ease instead of having to google every single term to figure out what Bootstrap class name you need for your site to perform the way you need it to.

On top of that the 5 projects are perfect to see how constructing a Website in Bootstrap can be done. Using navbars, collapsing, accordions, cards, slideshows, modals, flexbox, the grid system, and more, all with little to no JavaScript. The minimum JavaScript that did come with the course are from fun libraries like lightbox. Brad tosses in a few of these fun tools to show us how they work and how they are useful. 

Bottom-line, if you're looking to really grasp what Bootstrap can do and want the comprehensive documentation at your fingertips, this course is worth much more than what it costs. Pick it up now and start creating Responsive Front-End designs like a pro with Bootstrap4!

results.content:
The course is very fast paced and at times overwhelming. However, with the repetitive nature of the sections and the sandbox...I have the majority of Bootstrap locked into subconscious now. I've read several bad reviews before coming into this course and can see why so many gave a bad review. He is going fast...but like i mentioned previously...the repetitive nature of each video does lock most of the content into muscle memory. However, just like several other programming languages, you may be able to learn a few phrases to fumble around in Spanish, but repetition and time will make you more fluent.

Possibly one of the better instructors on Udemy. I've purchased almost all of his training lessons directly from his website. I don't expect to be a bootstrap programmer when I finish...I expect to have a better understanding of the language and build off that.

results.content:
Extremely informative course that walks you through a wealth of Bootstrap concepts.  The instructor has taken care to thoroughly explain each feature and starts off with a sandbox project demonstrating how to apply and use all the bootstrap classes.  I highly recommend sitting through this entire sandbox primer and rewatch it again if anything still seems confusing.  

After completing the primer it moves into a code-along where you build five real world projects using only a minimum Bootsrap boilerplate that you build yourself with Brad (This also provides a wonderful template you can reuse for your own projects). The projects take quite a bit of time to complete but they utilize nearly all of the concepts in Bootstrap and you'll get plenty of practice if you take the time to finish them.  They also come with some very nifty explanations and tricks.  There is some JavaScript in the course but generally no more than a few lines of code and the video walks you through the entire process.  Brad Traversy is also very good about making sure to regularly maintain his Udemy courses so you can count on your videos being current and up to date.

One thing I really appreciate is that the instructor doesn't edit out his mistakes, when he breaks his code you get to watch him troubleshoot it in real time which is somehow very encouraging when you're trying to learn a new language or framework.  This class was very useful to me and I hope it helps you understand Bootstrap as much as it helped me.

results.content:
thank you - very good introductory course to bootstrap 4. as a beginner bootstrap developer, i definitely benefited by being exposed to many of the bootstrap features and capabilities, while getting my hands on it during the projects.

an area of improvement would be to re-highlight/discuss how some of these features work while doing the project. the projects move at quite a rapid pace so i am often hitting pause to keep up while entering in the code myself.  and even though you are introduced to the key features during the sandbox section, it is difficult to recall all that is presented there.  the audience would benefit from being reminded of how some of the more complex features work along the way.
